port.title: The name of the serial port you want to connect to.
port.description: This is a specific name for a serial port. The device connected to this port may change on reboot, if multiple devices are connected to the system. It is the simplest option, so it should be prefeered if only one device is connected.

maufacturer.title: Name of the manufacturer of the desired device.
maufacturer.description: This name sould in most cases be the name of the manufacturer of the device. This may change and is mainly for human reference.

serialNumber.title: The serial number of your device.
serialNumber.description: This is a Hexadecimal number that should be unique for every device of this make and model. These originate from the usb serial controller and may not be programmed. You can spot if this is the case if it is only 4 - 5 characters lonng and has many zeros.

pnpId.title: The Pug'N'Play Id of your device.
pnpId.description: This originates from pre usb times and was for Plug and Play driver support. This will work with usb serial devices as well as with original serial ports.

device.title: Information about the device to use.
device.description: This part of the configuration is for identifying a unique device.

autoOpen.title: Automatically open connection
autoOpen.description: This defaults to true, so you only need to set it, if you want to prevent opening the device automatically.

baudRate.title: Speed of transmition
baudRate.description: This signifies how many bits are transmitted per second. Beware that there are dedicated values that are commonly used. Non-standard baud rates have to be supported by devices, converters and operatig systems so please avoid them if possible.

dataBits.title: The number of bits carrying data per packet.
dataBits.description: As Stated this signifies how many bits fo data are transported per packet. Most microcontroller based devices use 8 bits so 8 might a reasonable guess. 5 was standard in teletypes for a long time and also was commonly used to transpot data via punched tape.

lock.title: Exclusive access for this path
lock.description: This option can not be used on Windows! If set to false it allows other applications to access the same device at the same time. It defaults to true

stopBits.title: Number of bits that signify the end of a package
stopBits.description: This defaults to 1. What this values should be is written in the manual, in the datasheet or on the device it self ost of the times. In all other cases you could simply try both options.

parity.title: Mode of parity checking
parity.description: Parity checking is a way to detect simple transmittion errors. There are multiple modes of operation. This will most likely be given in the manual but most microcontroller boards dont use ist, so it defaults to 'none'

rtscts.title: use hardware flow control.
rtscts.description: If your device uses hardware flow control you will need two more wires beside RX and TX that are called CTS and RTS. You will have to refer to the mode of operation used by your device. There are multiple. usually you can find this information in the manual.

xon.title: Use XON software flow control.
xon.description: This enables software flow control on the side going to the device. This is most often used in conjunction to xoff. The Sender transfers a special character before it starts to transmit.

xoff.title: Use XOFF software flow control.
xoff.description: This enables software flow control on the side going to the computer. This is most often used in conjuction with xon. The Sender transmits a special character after the tranmission ended.

xany.title: Use XANY software flow control
xany.description: A special form of Software flow control. It uses XON/XOFF but if transmition is stopped every character will resume operation. On the other ones will only resume on a special character.

connection.title: Information about the serial communication.
connection.description: You can specify how the data should be transfered. With exception of the baud rate you will most likely not have to change any settings in this section if you only are using common microcontroller boards.

delimiter.title: Line ending delimiter
delimiter.description: This sequence is placed to signify the end of a line.

encoding.title: Character encoding used to transmit or receive
encoding.description: The characterencoding specified which bit sequence results in what character.

protocol.title: Information about the protocoll
protocol.description: At the moment only complete lines will be interpreted as data. This might expand in the future.
